texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My team at Red Hat depends heavily on  GitLab CI  and we build containers often to run all kinds of tests. Fortunately, GitLab offers up CI to build containers and a  container registry  in every repository to hold the containers we build.
texts.text: My team at Red Hat depends heavily on  GitLab CI  and we build containers often to run all kinds of tests. Fortunately, GitLab offers up CI to build containers and a  container registry  in every repository to hold the containers we build.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This is really handy because it keeps everything together in one place: your container build scripts, your container build infrastructure, and the registry that holds your containers. Better yet, you can put multiple types of containers underneath a single git repository if you need to build containers based on different Linux distributions.
texts.text: This is really handy because it keeps everything together in one place: your container build scripts, your container build infrastructure, and the registry that holds your containers. Better yet, you can put multiple types of containers underneath a single git repository if you need to build containers based on different Linux distributions.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Building with Docker in GitLab CI
texts.text: Building with Docker in GitLab CI

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: By default, GitLab offers up a  Docker builder  that works just fine. The CI system clones your repository, builds your containers and pushes them wherever you want. There's even a  simple CI YAML file  that does everything end-to-end for you.
texts.text: By default, GitLab offers up a  Docker builder  that works just fine. The CI system clones your repository, builds your containers and pushes them wherever you want. There's even a  simple CI YAML file  that does everything end-to-end for you.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: However, I have two issues with the Docker builder:
texts.text: However, I have two issues with the Docker builder:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='Larger images:'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='Larger images:'>]

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Building with buildah in GitLab CI
texts.text: Building with buildah in GitLab CI

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: On my local workstation, I use  podman  and  buildah  all the time to build, run, and test containers. These tools are handy because I don't need to remember to start the Docker daemon each time I want to mess with a container. I also don't need sudo.
texts.text: On my local workstation, I use  podman  and  buildah  all the time to build, run, and test containers. These tools are handy because I don't need to remember to start the Docker daemon each time I want to mess with a container. I also don't need sudo.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: All of my containers are stored beneath my home directory. That's good for keeping disk space in check, but it's especially helpful on shared servers since each user has their own unique storage. My container pulls and builds won't disrupt anyone else's work on the server and their work won't disrupt mine.
texts.text: All of my containers are stored beneath my home directory. That's good for keeping disk space in check, but it's especially helpful on shared servers since each user has their own unique storage. My container pulls and builds won't disrupt anyone else's work on the server and their work won't disrupt mine.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Finally, buildah offers some nice options out of the box. First, when you build a container with
texts.text: Finally, buildah offers some nice options out of the box. First, when you build a container with

texts.label: code
texts.orig: buildah bud
texts.text: buildah bud

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: , you end up with only three layers by default:
texts.text: , you end up with only three layers by default:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Original OS layer (example:
texts.text: Original OS layer (example:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Everything you added on top of the OS layer
texts.text: Everything you added on top of the OS layer

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Tiny bit of metadata
texts.text: Tiny bit of metadata

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This is incredibly helpful if you use package managers like
texts.text: This is incredibly helpful if you use package managers like

texts.label: code
texts.orig: dnf
texts.text: dnf

texts.label: code
texts.orig: apt
texts.text: apt

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: , and
texts.text: , and

texts.label: code
texts.orig: yum
texts.text: yum

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: that download a bunch of metadata before installing packages. You would normally have to clear the metadata carefully for the package manager so that your container wouldn't grow in size. Buildah takes care of that by squashing all the stuff you add into one layer.
texts.text: that download a bunch of metadata before installing packages. You would normally have to clear the metadata carefully for the package manager so that your container wouldn't grow in size. Buildah takes care of that by squashing all the stuff you add into one layer.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Of course, if you want to be more aggressive, buildah offers the
texts.text: Of course, if you want to be more aggressive, buildah offers the

texts.label: code
texts.orig: --squash
texts.text: --squash

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: option which squashes the whole image down into one layer. This can be helpful if disk space is at a premium and you change the layers often.
texts.text: option which squashes the whole image down into one layer. This can be helpful if disk space is at a premium and you change the layers often.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Getting started
texts.text: Getting started

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I have a repository called  os-containers  in GitLab that maintains fully updated containers for Fedora 29 and 30. The
texts.text: I have a repository called  os-containers  in GitLab that maintains fully updated containers for Fedora 29 and 30. The

texts.label: code
texts.orig: .gitlab-ci.yml
texts.text: .gitlab-ci.yml

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: file calls
texts.text: file calls

texts.label: code
texts.orig: build.sh
texts.text: build.sh

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: for two containers:  fedora29  and  fedora30 . Open the
texts.text: for two containers:  fedora29  and  fedora30 . Open the

texts.label: code
texts.orig: build.sh
texts.text: build.sh

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: file and follow along here:
texts.text: file and follow along here:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# Use vfs with buildah. Docker offers overlayfs as a default, but buildah
# cannot stack overlayfs on top of another overlayfs filesystem.
export STORAGE_DRIVER=vfs
texts.text:
# Use vfs with buildah. Docker offers overlayfs as a default, but buildah
# cannot stack overlayfs on top of another overlayfs filesystem.
export STORAGE_DRIVER=vfs

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: First off, we need to tell buildah to use the vfs storage driver. Docker uses overlayfs by default and stacking overlay filesystems will definitely lead to problems. Buildah won't let you try it.
texts.text: First off, we need to tell buildah to use the vfs storage driver. Docker uses overlayfs by default and stacking overlay filesystems will definitely lead to problems. Buildah won't let you try it.

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# Write all image metadata in the docker format, not the standard OCI format.
# Newer versions of docker can handle the OCI format, but older versions, like
# the one shipped with Fedora 30, cannot handle the format.
export BUILDAH_FORMAT=docker
texts.text:
# Write all image metadata in the docker format, not the standard OCI format.
# Newer versions of docker can handle the OCI format, but older versions, like
# the one shipped with Fedora 30, cannot handle the format.
export BUILDAH_FORMAT=docker

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: By default, buildah uses the  oci  container format . This sometimes causes issues with older versions of Docker that don't understand how to parse that type of metadata. By setting the format to
texts.text: By default, buildah uses the  oci  container format . This sometimes causes issues with older versions of Docker that don't understand how to parse that type of metadata. By setting the format to

texts.label: code
texts.orig: docker
texts.text: docker

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: , we're using a format that almost all container runtimes can understand.
texts.text: , we're using a format that almost all container runtimes can understand.

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# Log into GitLab's container repository.
export REGISTRY_AUTH_FILE=${HOME}/auth.json
echo "$CI_REGISTRY_PASSWORD" | buildah login -u "$CI_REGISTRY_USER" --password-stdin $CI_REGISTRY
texts.text:
# Log into GitLab's container repository.
export REGISTRY_AUTH_FILE=${HOME}/auth.json
echo "$CI_REGISTRY_PASSWORD" | buildah login -u "$CI_REGISTRY_USER" --password-stdin $CI_REGISTRY

texts.text: Here we set a path for the

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: that contains the credentials for talking to the container repository. We also use buildah to authenticate to GitLab's built-in container repository. GitLab automatically exports these variables for us (and hides them in the job output), so we can use them here.
texts.text: that contains the credentials for talking to the container repository. We also use buildah to authenticate to GitLab's built-in container repository. GitLab automatically exports these variables for us (and hides them in the job output), so we can use them here.

texts.label: code

texts.text: buildah bud -f builds/${IMAGE_NAME} -t ${IMAGE_NAME} .

buildah commit --squash $CONTAINER_ID $FQ_IMAGE_NAME
texts.text:

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Maintaining containers
texts.text: Maintaining containers

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: GitLab allows you to take things to the next level with CI schedules. In my repository, there is a schedule to build my containers once a day to catch the latest updates. I use these containers a lot and they need to be up to date before I can run tests.
texts.text: GitLab allows you to take things to the next level with CI schedules. In my repository, there is a schedule to build my containers once a day to catch the latest updates. I use these containers a lot and they need to be up to date before I can run tests.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If the container build fails for some reason, GitLab will send me an email to let me know.
texts.text: If the container build fails for some reason, GitLab will send me an email to let me know.
